fields.summary: Users fail to login to User Console on Eucalyptus 3.3 LDAP/AD Integrated Cloud

comments.body: [~hspencer], please continue to attempt to reproduce the problem.
After reading this, I assume it is something on the CLC side. If I'm wrong, please let me now and I'll help in any way I can.

Confirmed.

Steps to reproduce:

* Enable LDAP/AD integration on CLC
{code}
euca-modify-property -f authentication.ldap_integration_configuration=atliens-v2.lic
{code}
* Add user login profile for both admin user of account and user of account (since there is a known issue here - EUCA-6760 - used workaround suggested in known issue - i.e. use dummy password)
{code}
$ euare-userlistbypath --as-account account3
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/admin
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user22
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user21
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user30
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user26
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user25
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user24
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user23
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user29
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user27
arn:aws:iam::410851883146:user/user28
$ euare-useraddloginprofile --as-account account3 -u admin -p password
$ euare-useraddloginprofile --as-account account3 -u user24 -p password
$ euare-usergetloginprofile --as-account account3 -u admin
Login Profile Exists for User admin
$ euare-usergetloginprofile --as-account account3 -u user24
Login Profile Exists for User user24
* Observe login failure on Eucalyptus User Console
_Attached screen shots of login failures and sosreports from the CLC and User Console_
Screenshots and sosreports associated with reproduction.
This behavior is also seen in 3.2.2 as well.
Do we have a system in-house where this fails? Can I get access to investigate?

I'd like clarification. When you say the user console could not perform the login operation, is that from the user view, or from the CLC view? Did the user console log show "authenticated user <account>/<username>" ? That means the STS call worked and we got tokens. I was seeing that succeed, but the DescribeInstanceTypes failed.
I think where we were on the e-mail thread was that IAM was preventing access to this call and perhaps there was a specific policy to give access to this call? The policy the console team has been using grants access to everything, but that is probably not a preferred solution for customers.

Hey [~dkavanagh],

Not a problem.  The user could not log in using the Eucalyptus User Console, and would get presented with the following error:

{code}
An unexpected connection error occurred. Please try again later. If you continue experiencing problems, please contact your cloud administrator.
{code}

Additionally, I tested this before enabling LDAP sync (with the account webconsole, and user webuser1), and after enabling LDAP sync (using account1, and user01) - both failed to login using the Eucalyptus User Console.  The steps used for used for creating the webconsole account and webuser1 can be seen here:

https://gist.github.com/hspencer77/55808e12db469c88762e

When I did the testing with LDAP/AD sync enabled, I added the login profile and IAM policy (just like I did for the webuser1) for user01.  The error seen in the User Console was the same.  

The console log from when LDAP/AD sync was enabled, can be seen here:

https://gist.github.com/hspencer77/aecc083e3760e243308e

*Observation*

During this testing, I would also test logging into the Admin UI as well (in both cases).  Login to the Admin UI worked without a problem - just as long as I did the workaround mentioned in EUCA-6760 regarding the loginprofiles.
This is the error seen in 3.2.2.  This has been replicated in an in-house 3.2.2 testing environment.

Odd thing is, this began to work after the following was done:

* Remote 3.3 User Console was stopped.
* 3.3 User Console was started on the same machine of the 3.3 CLC/Walrus machine.
* A couple of stop/starts of the eucalyptus-cloud process and increasing the java heap size to 4Gs in the CLOUD_OPTS variable 

When I stopped the User Console on the CLC/Walrus machine, and restarted the remote User Console, it initially didn't work.  After a few hours, it began to work.  Need to figure out why it didn't work on the initial setup.  Nothing really points as to how this began to work.

Resetting user password and still the same issues.

Note: No IAM policies applied.  No change with IAM policies applied.

Hey [~lwade],

Did you implement the workaround by adding the loginprofile for the user with the dummy password, then adding the policy to allow all EC2 actions?  Note also, you will have to do this for every user who wants User Console access (due to EUCA-6760 regarding the _enable_ option in the LIC file).

We've not done this for a couple of users and they can login fine.  The login profile is only for the admin UI, not the user console from what I've seen.  Tried it anyhow and it didn't help.

Users without login profile can login just fine to the user console.  Troublesome user account has had a login profile applied and still cannot login.

Hey [~lwade],

The users that work, are they users from 3.2.2 or are these new users?  What about the users that fail?
[~hspencer], all new users. What we've noticed is that the ldiff of the troublesome users is about ~540 lines, twice the size of other users ldiff's.
[~lwade][~hspencer], please confirm the user console was upgraded to 3.3 that is connecting to the Eucalyptus 3.3.
[~kedwards], [~hspencer], confirmed, 3.3.0.1.

[~lwade],

Are you seeing any LDAP size limit errors during the LDAP sync (i.e. EUCA-6756)?
[~hspencer], nope.
Not size related, recreated with another user account which was short on attributes.

[~dshekhawat] found the following in logs:

{code}
Wed Jul 17 17:25:36 2013 TRACE [com.eucalyptus.ws.server.NioServerHandler.lookupPipeline(NioServerHandler.java):155] ============================================
HTTPHTTP/1.1 GET /services/Tokens?Action=GetSessionToken&DurationSeconds=43260&Version=2011-06-15
Accept-Encoding: identity
Authorization: Basic <BLABLABLA>
Connection: close
Host: localhost:8773
User-Agent: Python-urllib/2.6
============================================

============================================

Wed Jul 17 17:25:36 2013 TRACE [com.eucalyptus.records.BaseRecord.extreme(BaseRecord.java):198] PIPELINE_UNROLL :   [NioServerHandler.lookupPipeline.157] FilteredPipeline:name=tokens-query-pipeline:hashCode=-308513095:class=TokensQueryPipeline
Wed Jul 17 17:25:36 2013 TRACE [com.eucalyptus.ws.server.ServiceContextHandler.handleUpstream(ServiceContextHandler.java):204] Channel event: [id: 0x478bedf4] DISCONNECTED
Wed Jul 17 17:25:36 2013 TRACE [com.eucalyptus.ws.server.ServiceContextHandler.handleUpstream(ServiceContextHandler.java):204] Channel event: [id: 0x478bedf4] UNBOUND
Wed Jul 17 17:25:36 2013 TRACE [com.eucalyptus.ws.server.ServiceContextHandler.channelClosed(ServiceContextHandler.java):242] java.lang.NullPointerException
java.lang.NullPointerException
{code}

[~lwade] as discussed can you upload the tcpdump / ngrep on loopback interface on the CLC, while you try to use the UI to login?

That would have the exact call made with all the parameters as well as the response sent. This would immensely be helpful in debugging the problem.

[~kedwards] do you have any other thoughts ?
Users who cannot login have "@" in their AD password. Removing this allows them to login.  We should check special characters.
The login mechanism in the user console (and the CLC side) does allow any special characters in the password. This must be specific to the LDAP integration?
Correct, it certainly looks that way.

Looks like the issue is here:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/blob/master/clc/modules/authentication/src/main/java/com/eucalyptus/auth/ldap/LdapClient.java#L105-L114

We don't do anything special for strings (i.e. passwords) that have special characters in them.  When passing the [password|http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/javax/naming/Context.html#SECURITY_CREDENTIALS], we probably have to do something to the [string and pass a character set so that its sent properly|http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#String(byte\[\], java.nio.charset.Charset)] I am thinking.

[~kedwards]/[~sjones], what do you guys think - could this be an issue?

Harold, It is impossible to tell looking at that code. That's simply a function call with the password passed in. If the value goes over the wire, it "might" need to be encoded, but without digging deeper, we don't know if that's already being done, or if it needs to be done at all.
[~hspencer], I agree with [~dkavanagh] regarding the next steps on this issue.  Further investigation is required to determine the root cause.

[~kedwards] and [~dkavanagh], I was just going off what the LDAP API expects for character encoding for password (IIRC, it expects UTF-8), but I understand what you guys are saying.  Didn't know if that would be helpful or not.  Thanks for the responses.  Hopefully we can see something on the wire that will help us out here.
Dup of EUCA-7035
